1. A 67-year-old male with a history of poorly controlled hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus presents with sudden, painless vision loss in his right eye upon waking. He describes the vision loss as a dark, blurred area in the nasal half of his visual field that developed over several hours. He denies any eye pain but notes mild headaches over the past week. On examination, his visual acuity in the right eye is 20/100, with a relative afferent pupillary defect present. Fundoscopic exam reveals a swollen, pale optic disc with splinter hemorrhages. The left eye is unaffected with normal visual acuity and optic disc appearance. Laboratory studies show elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) but normal C-reactive protein (CRP). The clinical picture is consistent with non-arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (NAION) likely due to vascular insufficiency from his underlying conditions.
